hero.title: Breeding Philosophy
hero.subtitle:
At Ratopia Rattery, I treat breeding as a highly human-directed—and irreversible—act of selection.

It is not a simple continuation of “natural reproduction”, but a process in which humans decide which traits are kept, which risks are amplified, and which lives are allowed to enter the future. Precisely because breeding is not “natural”, it cannot be neutral, and it cannot be effortless. I refuse to romanticize breeding as “the continuation of life”, and I also refuse to reduce it to “output and efficiency”. In my view, breeding is a technical practice that carries responsibility toward a future population: every pairing is a wager on temperament, health, structure, and risk; every act of negligence returns—at a higher cost—in the next generations.

body.text:
Any goal-oriented selection program inevitably faces trade-offs. Denying the existence of culling does not eliminate it—it merely pushes it into less visible and less controllable forms: widespread poor growth, higher rates of chronic illness, or the full transfer of problems onto future keepers.

I choose to acknowledge this reality directly, and to move culling forward in the process—defined, categorized, and structured—rather than disguising it after the fact.

1. Hard culling:

Hard culling mainly occurs early in life (usually within the first month). This window is not arbitrary—it reflects both the biology of rats and the practical realities of breeding.

Rats can produce large litters, but a dam’s milk supply, recovery capacity, and energy have clear limits. When the number of pups significantly exceeds what the mother can sustain, “everyone survives” may be only an appearance. The underlying outcome is often long-term competition for nutrition, slower overall development, weaker immune foundations, and a markedly higher risk of disease later.

In that situation, refusing to control numbers does not solve the ethical problem—it simply delays it, shifting the question from “who survives” to “how well anyone can survive long-term”, while forcing every pup to share the same hidden costs.

For this reason, when necessary I will carry out early litter-size control so that the pups who remain can receive adequate nutrition, stable developmental rhythms, and a stronger foundation for long-term health.

Hard culling may also occur under certain conditions, including:

Clear failure to thrive (FTT); severe and irreversible developmental abnormalities; or when, during pairing, pregnancy, or the postpartum period, the parents reveal significant temperament or health issues that make the entire litter a systemic and unacceptable risk.

2. Soft culling:

Soft culling means explicitly removing an individual from the breeding program and not continuing that line. This is the most frequently used—and most important—form of risk control in our practice. Unlike hard culling, it does not involve ending a life; it is a deliberate restriction of breeding eligibility.

Its core message can be stated simply: not every animal that survives and appears healthy is suitable for breeding.

Soft culling is strongly considered when we see any of the following:

Unstable temperament, including aggression or high reactivity; uncertain health status even if no obvious disease is present; structural conformation that cannot support long-term activity and physical load; repeated or unacceptable risk signals within the genetic background.

The essence of soft culling is stopping “possible problems” in the current generation rather than hoping “the next generation will be better”.

In my philosophy, ending a line is not a failure. Continuing to breed while knowing the risks is what is truly irresponsible.

In fast-reproducing species like rats and mice—where generations turn over quickly and genetics reveal themselves rapidly—inbreeding is not an abnormality but an unavoidable technical tool. The question is never simply “whether to inbreed”, but whether inbreeding is done within records, purpose, and boundaries. I oppose “unconscious inbreeding”, and I also oppose treating “never inbreeding at all” as moral superiority.

Inbreeding refers to high-intensity pairings such as parent–offspring or full-sibling matings. This is only used on a very small scale and under highly controlled conditions, with prerequisites that include:

Complete, continuous, and traceable pedigree records; explicit calculation and monitoring of the inbreeding coefficient; and a clear validation goal—rather than breeding simply for the sake of “continuing the line”.

The purpose of inbreeding is straightforward: to deliberately increase genetic pressure so that hidden defects become visible earlier.

This logic closely parallels the way laboratory inbred strains are established: in research, inbreeding is used to achieve genetic uniformity; in companion-animal breeding, it is used to test stability and to identify and settle risks.

If a line cannot withstand inbreeding pressure, then the problem is not “caused by inbreeding”. The problem was already present—only masked by randomness.

Linebreeding is our long-term core strategy. It allows us to consolidate temperament, health, and structural traits that have already been validated, while keeping risk within manageable bounds. By breeding within a line, we reduce random variation, make outcomes more predictable, and make long-term evaluation and correction more feasible.

By contrast, outcrossing without a clear objective or complete records is not automatically safer.

In many cases, outcrossing merely delays or shifts problems—and may even introduce new, uncontrollable variables. Therefore, I do not reject outcrossing, but I strongly reject treating it as a universal “reset the gene pool” solution.

Extreme selection is often the most noticeable path in the short term, and the easiest to receive immediate market feedback. But in rodent breeding, extreme selection almost never comes with a single isolated cost.

When one trait is repeatedly pushed to an extreme, what usually follows is hidden deterioration in other traits, increased fragility of the overall genetic background, and reduced tolerance to environment, stress, and disease.

These issues may not concentrate in the first generation. Instead, they often erupt after several generations—when the line has already lost room to correct.

Rejecting extreme selection is not “conservatism”. It is an understanding that extreme choices create path dependence: once you go far enough, the cost of turning back multiplies, and sometimes there is no way back.

For this reason, I care more about whether a population remains stable after multiple generations than whether one generation looks “outstanding”. I would rather give up short-term eye-catching results than bet on an irreversible direction.

I do not treat breeding as a natural right.
In our system, not entering the breeding program is the default.

This does not mean an individual is unhealthy or not excellent. It means breeding is a high-risk act: it magnifies individual problems into population problems, and turns a choice made today into long-term consequences.

Therefore, in practice I always start with the question “do we have sufficient reason to breed”, rather than “why not breed”.

This means not every healthy, well-tempered individual will be bred; not every generation must produce offspring; and proactively ending a line is a normal decision, not a signal of failure.

If a breeding program must constantly “prove that it is breeding”, then it has likely already been captured by breeding itself.

Responsibility does not end when pups are born, leave the rattery, or are adopted.

Many of the most important issues—temperament stability, chronic health risk, genetic defects—only become visible on a longer timescale. For this reason, I do not assume that “every breeding decision is correct”. Instead, I assume errors will occur, and the difference is simply whether we are willing to bear the consequences.

Bearing consequences means acknowledging that a pairing or direction was wrong; stopping that direction completely when necessary; and refusing to maintain an existing plan through excuses, minimization, or shifting responsibility.

In my philosophy, what is truly unacceptable is not failure, but continuing forward while knowingly ignoring problems.
